column1: Highlands Ranch is a census-designated place (CDP) in Douglas County
column2: Colorado
column4: 713 at the 2010 census. Located 12 miles (19 km) south of Denver
column5: Highlands Ranch is an unincorporated community  and was the twelfth-most populous CDP in the United States in 2010.

column1: Like many parts of the Colorado Front Range
column2: the first residents of the area were Native Americans. The area was populated by a number of nomadic tribes
column4: Cheyenne and Arapaho tribes. Because it was part of the Mississippi River Drainage Area
column5: it was stolen by France by French explorer René-Robert Cavelier
column6: Sieur de La Salle and it was named as part of "Louisiana" in 1682. The Spanish gained Louisiana in 1763
column7: and returned it to France in 1801. This area of what is now Northern Douglas County
column8: was in the Louisiana Purchase when it was sold to the United States in 1803.

column1: The Stephen Harriman Long Expedition of 1820 entered the area at the beginning of July 1820. That was the first documented exploration of the area by European or United States explorers.Much of the Denver Metro Area began to be settled as ranch land starting in 1859
column2: but because of a lack of water in the area
column3: it was not permanently settled until around 1870. The first legal settler of the area was Curtis H. Field
column4: who purchased land just on the west side of Santa Fe Drive from the US government on February 25
column5: 1870.The Highlands Ranch Mansion (or "Castle Isabel") was built over a period of several years
column6: from 1891 to 1904. The first owner of the house was Samuel Allan Long
column7: who purchased a 40-acre homestead in northern Douglas County in 1884 and later expanded it to a 2
column8: 000-acre farm. By 1891 he had built a modest farmhouse on the property and called it Rotherwood after a boyhood farm. The name "Rotherwood"
column9: a reference to a boyhood farm of Long's
column10: was found etched above the original front door that led experts to believe so. According to the Highlands Ranch Metro District website
column11: Long was a prominent innovator of dry land farming techniques in Colorado during the late 19th century.

column1: John W. Springer bought the ranch in 1898 and built the Highlands Ranch Mansion. He built it up to a 10
column2: 000 acre ranch and farm. It was called "Castle Isabel" for a time for his second wife Isabel Patterson Springer. He began selling off parts of the ranch in 1911. The mansion underwent a renovation from 2010-2012 that was funded by Shea Homes.

column1: The Colorado Gold Rush brought people to Colorado in droves during the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The city of Denver
column2: located approximately 12 miles to the north
column3: grew considerably during this time. However
column4: the area remained a series of farms and ranches
column5: and many residents would visit the town of Littleton
column7: when they needed to purchase clothing

column1: The Springer land was bought and sold several times throughout the 1920s and 1930s. In 1937 it was bought by Lawrence C. Phipps
column2: Jr.
column3: who used it to raise cattle and hunt fox. After Phipps died in 1976
column4: the land was bought by Marvin Davis
column5: the owner of an oil company.

column2: a large parcel of land in unincorporated Douglas County was purchased by The Mission Viejo Company. As the suburbs of Denver expanded
column3: the company desired to build a new planned suburb
column6: akin to its first planned development of Mission Viejo
column7: California. Initial plans were drawn up
column8: many of which are still being realized. These plans laid out several major streets and called for several schools and recreation centers
column9: as well as a town center and public library. Large parcels of land were sold to private housing developers
column10: such as Richmond Homes. As these developments appeared
column11: they often carried their own names
column12: creating a series of segmented neighborhoods throughout Highlands Ranch. Plans for Highlands Ranch also included a snaking "green belt" which provided for undeveloped land for recreation. The plans also allowed for a large number of public parks and bike paths.

column1: The first homes in Highlands Ranch were built in 1981
column2: near South Broadway. Simultaneously
column3: the state built a new freeway through the area
column5: which opened in 1985. Many of the first residents of Highlands Ranch complained about the initial lack of commercial development. Residents had to drive many miles (usually into Littleton) for groceries
column7: or medical care. The first public school
column9: opened in 1982. The same year also saw the completion of the Northridge Recreation Center
column10: an athletic club available to all Highlands Ranch homeowners. The first secondary school
column12: opened in 1987. This institution became solely a high school
column14: in 1991 with the building of nearby Cresthill Middle School. The first Highlands Ranch branch of Douglas County Libraries also opened in 1991
column15: housed in a strip mall off Broadway and Springer Drive.

column2: the population of Highlands Ranch increasingly expanded. Highlands Ranch celebrated its 10th anniversary in 1991 with a population of 17
column3: 000 residents. Over the next ten years
column4: Highlands Ranch continued to develop on a large scale.

column2: The Mission Viejo Company was acquired by Shea Properties
column3: which continued to expand the community. This included bringing a regional office of Lucent Technologies
column4: and later in the same complex Avaya Communication
column5: to the area. The year 2000 saw the opening of a much larger Highlands Ranch Library as well as the establishment of the Highlands Ranch Chamber of Commerce. The 470 freeway is being expanded as well
column6: adding HOV toll lanes in each direction from Interstate 25 to Wadsworth Boulevard (SH-121).

column2: two students opened fire at the STEM School Highlands Ranch
column3: killing one student and injuring 8 others. The school is located near to Columbine High School

column1: Highlands Ranch celebrated its 25th anniversary in 2006
column2: reporting a population of 86
column3: 000 residents. Despite a growing number of local businesses
column4: Highlands Ranch has often been labeled as the "bubble" of Denver. Many residents commute to Downtown Denver or the Denver Technological Center.

column5: Highlands Ranch is 13 miles (21 km) south of downtown Denver and 13 miles (21 km) north-northwest of Castle Rock
column6: the county seat.According to the United States Census Bureau
column7: the CDP has a total area of 24.29 square miles (62.9 km2) of which 24.26 square miles (62.8 km2) is land and 0.03 square miles (0.078 km2) is water.As a suburb of Denver
column8: Highlands Ranch is part of both the greater Denver metropolitan area and the Front Range Urban Corridor. It borders several other Denver suburbs including Littleton and Centennial to the north and Acres Green and Lone Tree to the east. In addition
column9: Highlands Ranch borders Chatfield State Park to the west. As Highlands Ranch is a CDP
column10: its boundaries are defined by the U.S. Census Bureau and have no legal standing.

column1: Highlands Ranch is an unincorporated community within Douglas County. Most municipal services
column2: such as the construction and upkeep of arterial roads
column4: are performed by the Highlands Ranch Metro District
column5: a special district under state law
column6: which is funded mostly by property taxes and state lottery funds. Highlands Ranch is policed by Douglas County Sheriffs Office
column7: with South Metro Fire Rescue providing fire protection
column8: and all public schools are part of the Douglas County School System.

column2: all Highlands Ranch residents are asked to sign and follow a community covenant as dictated by the Highlands Ranch Community Association or "HRCA". This covenant places firm guidelines on such issues as housing decoration
column4: and contribution to the area's library and recreation centers. The Highlands Ranch Community Association obtains its funding through common homeowner association fees and covenant violation fines and
column6: is not usually recognized as a government
column7: but rather as a local non-profit organization.Highlands Ranch lies within Colorado's 6th U.S. Congressional District. For the purposes of representation in the Colorado General Assembly
column8: the CDP is located in the 30th district of the Colorado Senate and the 39th and 43rd districts of the Colorado House of Representatives.ZIP codes 80126
column11: and 80163 – assigned by default to the adjacent City of Littleton – serve Highlands Ranch.
